This movie will not win any Oscars, I would guess, but it's a heck of a lot of fun.

Jeff Bridges was great, and It's nice to see a female star who is played as just smart, attractive and solidly in control rather than a brainless bimbo.

Ryan Reynolds does a solid job too. Great special effects.

I'd say a cross between Dead Like me and Men In Black.

Don't listen to the critics, this film was a blast to watch.
I saw this movie in theaters and absolutely loved it. It was filmed slightly different than most movies I've seen which was very cool, and Ryan Reynolds and Jeff Bridges did a phenomenal job.

INTRO

So, the movie starts off with Nick (Played by Ryan Reynolds) and Roy (Played by Jeff Bridges, I believe he's found his calling) chasing a very large CGI Scottish man, that makes Fat Bastard look attractive, and we're told that just 4 days earlier Nick had no idea he would be doing this.

Cut to the next scene and Nick is digging in his back yard and we see that he buries what appear to be pieces of Gold and marks the spot by putting an Orange tree on top of it (An Orange tree in Boston? Hmm).  The movie then cuts to a scene where he's waking up and his girlfriend is telling him there's an orange tree and the back yard.  Nick then goes to work as a member of the Boston Police Department where he tells his partner Hayes (Played by Kevin Bacon) that he cannot keep the gold and he's going to turn it into evidence.  Hayes says, I've been feeling the same way and I'm going to do the same.

Next up, the two partners (Nick and Hayes) are leading a raid on the biggest Meth House in the city.  One thing leads to another and Nick goes chasing the kingpin of the Meth operation up several flights of stairs where, he runs into Hayes who tips him off that he's the kingpin, tells him he cannot let him turn the gold in, and then proceeds to shoot Nick in the face where by, Nick falls 3 stories to his death.  Upon his ascent to judgement Nick is intercepted by the R.I.P.D or Rest In Peace Department where, he is told that this is his only chance to redeem himself of being a crooked cop and he agrees.  Before you know it, he's being partnered up Roy who coincidentally was also murdered by his own partner.

THE STORY AND SCRIPT

Keep in mind, we're still within the first 20 minutes of the movie and we've already set the stage for what will be an interesting story that comes off without being predictable even if it doesn't have many plot twists.  The partners and their lines are both colorful enough and yet different enough to keep you entertained.

The Script itself, has few holes, plenty of action, some very funny dialogue, and as I said before it is overall very entertaining.

THE CHARACTERS

Nick seems to me to be just another Ryan Reynolds part where more of Ryan comes out than Nick but, over all he doesn't distract from the movie.

Roy is a sober version of Rooster Cogburn but, I seriously welcomed this as that role was Jeff Bridges best acting job in my opinion!  I very much like that he brought this presence and atmosphere to this movie.

Hayes has a bit of a two faced edge two him and honestly comes off with a little bit of a Tyler Durden leadership presence without the multiple personality disorder.  Not a bad job here by Kevin Bacon but, not up to his acting in X-Men First Class.

THE EFFECTS

I don't know why but, CGI has been annoying the heck out of me lately and this movie is no different.  I think the problem with CGI is that it is an attempt to bring to life the visions we all had as kids but, it does this through computers that are clearly missing something. So, for me, my imagination just always seemed more real growing up and these effects just aren't living up to the presence that the likes of Lucas Arts, Industrial Light and Magic, and many other effects groups brought to the table.

So, were the effects bad?  No but, they weren't realistic either.  Kind of like the way Lou Ferigno's hulk was very realistic and the latest Avengers version of the Hulk looks good but, he's clearly animated and nobody would ever question that.

OVERALL

I really liked this movie, it was entertaining and fun without being too serious.  Was it like Men in Black?  I thought it was going to be at first but, to me the story wasn't as far fetched and neither were the villains.  I would also sooner believe that Bridges is a Frontier Lawman and Reynolds is a modern cop before I would believe that either Will Smith or Tommy Lee Jones were any serious lawmen.

Should you see this movie?  If you're looking for an entertaining escape from reality?  Sure I would say go see it but, if you're the type that hates all things fantasy, then you might want to pass this one up.

for the record, I would not say this is a 4 star movie but, it doesn't deserve a 3 either so maybe 3.5 stars would be more appropriate or 7 out of 10 as it was a good movie but, not a blockbuster.

There are several signs that a film is destined to fail.  First and foremost, if the film in question doesn't allow for advanced viewing by critics, it's usually a tell-tale sign that the movie studio knows it's bad and doesn't want negative reviews to damage the opening weekend numbers.  Secondly, a massive budget is difficult to overcome, even for an average film with an A-list actor starring in it.  For instance, Green Lantern and Catwoman - two incredibly popular comic book characters - both managed to crash-and-burn at the box office despite the A-list star-power.  Thirdly, if a film looks like a recently released film, potential moviegoers will often balk at seeing the same thing twice.  This is the recent Olympus Has Fallen vs. White House Down predicament.  Finally, if there is other films debuting on the same weekend, odds are the audience will be split amongst the variety of choices, ultimately leading to lower than usual viewers.  Naturally, every one of these factors is weighing heavily on the sure-to-fail comic book-to-film adaptation, Rest in Peace Department (R.I.P.D.).

Directed by Robert Schwentke (RED, The Time Traveler's Wife), R.I.P.D. stars Ryan Reynolds as Boston police officer, Nick Walker.  After a drug bust with his partner, Bobby Hayes (Kevin Bacon), the pair decides to keep a handful of valuable gold pieces.  However, Nick feels guilty about his misdeed and prepares to do the right thing by putting the gold into evidence.  However, before he can do so he is unexpectedly betrayed and murdered.  Now a member of the afterlife, he is given a choice to become an afterlife police officer or face his final judgment (as a dirty cop).  Now teamed with a new partner, Roy Pulsipher (Jeff Bridges), the duo must work through their differences to stop an ancient artifact from being constructed, which would allow the dead to return to Earth.  Mary-Louise Parker, Stephanie Szostak, James Hong, and Marisa Miller also star in supporting roles.

From the second the first trailer debuted, R.I.P.D. has received an endless amount of criticism for resembling the storyline and characters featured in Men in Black.  While the premise of R.I.P.D. is sound, it does play off Men in Black far too much for comfort to feel like a fresh idea.  Clearly, the story was inspired by a concept of "Men in Black meet the Ghostbusters," but in the weak (and brief) defense of R.I.P.D., most of the films being released these days resemble some other film that's been previously released.  It's fairly easy to cope with the fact that this film is an utter knock-off (intended or not) as long as it provides for an interesting story, intriguing characters, and a plot that doesn't seem too "off the wall."  Sadly, R.I.P.D. fails in each and every one of these categories, leaving a completely disingenuous and unsettling feeling of being ripped off.  Like the previously mentioned comic film failures, Green Lantern (also starring Ryan Reynolds) and Catwoman, plus the easily comparable Jonah Hex, it's easy to imagine the sound of money being flushed down the toilet about a quarter of the way through this film.  It's just that nostalgically predictable.

Easily the brightest spot of this film is the acting of Academy Award winner, Jeff Bridges, who once again adopts the "True Grit" accent, portraying a western lawman with an overzealous attitude and habit of ignoring the rules.  Like the majority of his roles over the course of his career, he's extremely likeable, full of charisma, and playfully humorous.  He fits into the role of the cranky westerner quite well (much like Tommy Lee Jones in Men in Black), adding the majority of the humor to this film in a sarcastic, and occasionally jumbled manner.  On the other hand, his partner (Ryan Reynolds) doesn't fare so well in the role of the "sympathetic" lead, often coming off as bland and stale.  Truth be told, Ryan Reynolds needs to lay off the comic book films for a while and stick to serious roles.  For a guy that came into the business doing comedy roles, Reynolds is hardly ever funny anymore.  Somewhere along the way he lost his flair for comedy, and is much more suited for roles that resemble his characters in Safe House or Buried.  However, many of us are still holding on to the small shred of hope that a Deadpool movie is still in the works (yes, he should get a hall pass to make that film).

Overall, R.I.P.D. will leave a mostly negative impression on the few people that do end up watching it - for a wide variety of reasons, starting with a predicable story, weak villainy, and sub-par CGI.  The film does have its moments of action and comedy, but this sub-genre of sci-fi action, mixed with the premise of new partners bonding while killing aliens needs to be given a rest.  Like the first Men in Black film, R.I.P.D. would have easily been a hit if it was released in 1997 - but that was 16 years ago.  The rookie being partnered with the cranky old man "bromance" has run its course, and that's never been more evident than after watching this film.  Actually, it was pretty evident after watching Men in Black III, too, but somehow that film still managed to be commercially successful.  In any event, there are better things to do with 90 minutes of your life than to watch this film, and depending on how desperate you are when this film hits home video, it might garner a sympathy rental - but, absolutely nothing more.

GRADE: D

I'll say right up front I've never seen a Men in Black movie (Will Smith leaves me VERY cold as an actor) so I don't know nor do I care if this film is similar (how many 'Hangover' type films have come out in the last few years, several of which are as good or better than the original?) but this film was quite enjoyable. I liked the humor and the silly plot didn't bother me a bit.  Kevin Bacon's role seems a bit slight but Bacon is a very good actor who's had many underwritten roles and he knows how to overcome them.  I wish James Hong and Marisa Miller's roles had been a bit expanded but the notion behind their roles is a pretty good one.  This isn't a great film but it's a pretty good way to spend an hour and a half.  I hope Bridges and Parker team up again soon in another movie.  Recommended.

"Un-dead police officers?" Really? C'mon! This PG-13 action-fest once again had me scanning my mental Thesaurus... Absurd? Ludicrous? Preposterous? Ridiculous? Outrageous? Goofy? Hilarious? I think you get the picture. If you've seen the ads you know a recently slain cop joins a team of undead police officers in the Rest In Peace Department.

This goofy comedy, written by Phil Hay/Matt Manfridi ("Clash of the Titans") and directed by Robert Schwentke ("Red") is a sure-fire winner, full of action, comedy and Computer Generated Imaging. I freely admit that there were times things got too, too silly and my interest faltered, but then the story rallied again.

We watch:
  * Jeff Bridges ("Hearts of the West") is Roy, wearing a Buffalo Bill beard and mumbling like he has a lower lip full of chewing tobacco; he's an old-time lawman on the third sixty-year extension of his assignment.
  * Marisa Miller (Victoria's Secret model) in her slinky gold dress, is Roy's avatar when he walks among us.
  * Ryan Reynolds ("Chaos Theory") is Nick, slain by his trusted partner and stunned by this new turn of events. He quickly adjusts to the idea that he can't be killed any more, at least THAT is a relief!
  * James Hong ("Safe") is Nick's avatar.
  * Mary Louise Parker ("Red") is Proctor, the R.I.P.D. orientation officer in her short black uniform and white knee-length go-go boots...she made me think of Diana Rigg.
  * Kevin Bacon ("Frost/Nixon") is Officer Hayes, ready and willing to comfort his partner's widow.

The CGI technicians had a blast and the audience saw blowie uppie stuff galore! Our poor heroes are really up against big-time trouble: Global Warming, the Black Plague and bad cell-phone reception. At least Amazon will tell us when the DVD is available.

-----------------A NO-SPOILER REVIEW ZONE. -------------------
Absolute fun riot stuffed full of both easy jokey lines and deliciously twisty, weird semi-demi-philosophical banter that I could not get enough of! Nearly non-stop *big* action and real-enough paranormal effects...plus outrageous, terrific acting by Ryan Reynolds, Jeff Bridges, Mary Louise Parker, Kevin Bacon.  By 2013 I'd pretty much had my fill of Zombie movies, and this was a fun, genius take on other possibilities for dead dudes. And dudesses.

The bizarro rules of RIPD's universe of (sort-of) resurrected cowboy lawmen, corrupt cops, invading "Dead -Ohs", and the comically efficient bureaucrats of some Eternal Mystery Management Team/ God/s actually had enough logic to anchor the ongoing outrageous action sequences, side stories... and Looming Cosmic Battle. I watch this movie every Christmas/Hannukah just to keep the Holiday drama in perspective.

And nope, it certainly is *not* a repeat of GHOST BUSTERS, as a couple of critics said back in 2013. They had clearly forgotten GB to come up with that. My take on the panning of the film was that RIPD was so outrageously different in its paranormal horror, thriller, comedy mashupness, that many critics were too lazy to abandon their rubber stamp classification routine. RIPD --like Jeff Bridges' other great dark comedy hit THE GREAT LEBOWSKI-- violates simple categories.

I can see how this film might send a little DID I JUST SEE THAT??!!! shock up the spines of both absolute atheists and fundamentalist Christians. I think that's a good thing. And it's why I suspect there was some boycotting of RIPD.

AND THEN THERE'S THIS DEPT.: Jeff Bridges' resurrected cowboy lawman has genius and often showstopper lines; he carries the movie. It's because of the accuracy of the 1870s cowboy lawman lingo --more wordy in the kind of near-Biblical way of speaking, kind of Mark Twain, that I think it's hard to catch the jokes-within-jokes and multiple irony going on. Back in the day, many Americans living on farms and ranches learned to read from the King James vers. of the Bible. You can see it in newspapers from that era, as well. They didn't talk like comic book and vid game characters then, so R.I.P.D. has some historical accuracy built into this rich, character. The aging lawman also has a bit of kink going on with his supervisor...which spiced up the cop-buddy film aspects to keep it interesting on a whole other level.

Don't miss RIPD.  It was great action + hilarious writing + some of the best pacing in any film, make that any kind of film, ever.

SIDE NOTE FOR EDUCATORS: If you teach philosophy, religion, or film, I'm betting you'd generate great discussions by screening or assigning RIPD for your class.

I'll just make this short and sweet - (Minor Spoilers) I had never heard of this movie until it was on a premium cable station some time back and fortunately I caught it right at the beginning (Ryan Reynolds is always someone to catch your attention). I honestly absolutely loved it! Is it totally stupid and cartoonish? Yes! Are there stupid yet clever jokes throughout? Absolutely. There's even a silly little love story (not Ryan's with his wife) for Jeff Bridges. The point is, this movie isn't supposed to be realistic in any way - like that stupid "Pixel" movie, except this one was actually funny. It's a funny ride of Ryan wanting revenge for his own death, Ryan and Jeff learning to work together, Ryan and Jeff in their alter-egos (some of the funniest moments are Jeff in his "woman" alter-ego), Jeff's "secret crush" on the woman in charge of him, and them trying to chase down and send the "dead-os" back to where they belong while they stop the worst Dead-O, Kevin Bacon. Quite honestly, I'd love to see a sequel made but I don't think it made enough money. Is this movie for everyone? Absolutely not. I generally hate really stupid-funny movies but this had me laughing all the way through. My husband absolutely hated it, I loved it, so you'll have to judge for yourself (as you can see, the star-counts are pretty equal down the column. I've been wanting to buy this but now that it's out on 3D and we have the 3D equipment, it's being added to my collection. It's just a cute, stupid, funny, eye-roller type of flick.

I've seen this movie several times already.  It is true that it has some resemblance to 'MIB' (Men In Black) but not much! So much of the dialogue is spoken absolutely dead-pan, no over-the-top hipness or larger-than-life characters like Rip Torn. Jeff Bridges does sport a twangy drawl, as did Tommy Lee Jones. However, the similarities stop there.

There is a running gag throughout the movie about what the Jeff Bridges character finds sexy in women. It has to do with the time he lived in (the 1800s). The body he gets on earth this time around is wasted on such a character.

Ryan Reynolds is perfectly paired with Bridges. The very last scene is so funny, such a fitting ending and new beginning, for both characters.

The truly wonderful thing about  'RIPD' is its pace. It rambles along, like the shoot-em-up lawmen these characters are. There aren't any slow patches, there aren't any speedy segments. It is just like a wonderful comic book read - and that is where the story comes from. Good work!

I love it when a book or movie has, as one of its focuses, the afterlife, and how characters get a second chance to improve their lot, even if I don't believe that we get a chance after death quite like this movie shows us.

Nick and Roy, before the beginning of the movie, found some gold, and rather than turning it in to evidence, they each keep half. But Nick has afterthoughts, and decides he is going to turn in his gold. So, we might say that his soul is, perhaps, approximately 50% evil and 50% good, so after his partner Roy kills him (to get the gold), he finds himself offered a chance to help the Rest In Peace Department (R.I.P.D.) for a hundred years before judgment.

This is a theme of other literature. In the Incarnations of Immortality Series by Piers Anthony, souls who die with a 50% balance on their souls get a chance to assist that major Incarnations in Purgatory, while waiting to see if their balance can change.

I would assume that in both cases, the balance is affected more by what we do in life than by what we do after death, so even if you believe that we might get a chance to improve our chances at judgment after death, we must be aware that making the right decisions DURING LIFE will have a much bigger effect on our soul's balance than what we do after death.

Nick and Roy, his new partner in R.I.P.D., work together to bring escaped souls back to justice, not earthly justice, but heavenly justice, but they do have the ability to be judge, jury and executioner when they need to be, when it is obvious that a soul has no redeeming value, using a white bullet that removes their soul entirely from the cosmos, never to return again.

This is an excellent film that gives us one view of the Afterlife.

Defending Your Life is another great film that shows us the Afterlife.

Pier's Anthony's eight book series, The Incarnations of Immortality, looking at humans becoming and serving as the incarnations of Death, Time, Fate, War, Mother Earth, Evil, Good, and Night, is another excellent resource. (As you might guess, Incarnations is one of my favorite series of books, I've read the first book, "On a Pale Horse" at least eight or ten times.

I highly recommend R.I.P.D. to your enjoyment.

R.I.P.D. is... a complicated thing.  It's based on a Dark Horse comic, but it's also kind of a rip-off of Men in Black.  Men in Black the film, not the comic.  It looks like they intended to achieve the same success as the MiB not by following the same procedure and adapting the story in a way that'd be more fitting and interesting for its world, but by simply redoing MiB but exchanging "aliens" for "dead people".

But I'm getting ahead of myself.  The film stars Ryan Reynolds as Nick, a policeman who steals gold from a drug bust with his partner Bobby (played by Kevin Bacon, which sort of ruins any suspense into realizing who's going to be the villain), but then he gets second thoughts and wants out.  Not wanting to take any chances, Bobby murders Nick in the middle of a firefight.  After he hits the floor, Nick is lifted into a portal to the afterlife, where he is taken to the R.I.P.D., a place where he's given the opportunity to use his skills as policeman instead of going to purgatory.  There, he's joined by Roy (Jeff Bridges), former Civil War fighter, as his new partner, in order to pursue and arrest "deadoes", renegade souls who refuse to go on and so turn into monsters.  But then they're dragged into a plot by the deadoes to escape hell and invade the Earth and Nick's stolen gold is a key element.

So, let's check onto the list of cliches, shall we? Buddy cops who can't stand each other at first but warm up to each other at the end? Check.  Trigger-happy cowboy with an accent who shoots first and aks questions later? Check. Policeman runs into catastrophic scenario in his first day? Check.  Guy who wants out from a crime and doesn't even suspect he might be killed for it? Check.  Villain who lets himself be easily captured so he can wreak havoc at the heroes headquarters? Check.  Kidnapping the hero's girlfriend at the climax? Check.  And many, MANY more.

Then there are the specific rip-offs.  Besides the obvious MiB vibe, there are obvious plot points from Ghost, and the whole "dead souls refusing to move on and staying to wander on Earth, turning into monsters" is something I vividly remember from somewhere else, but it's killing me that I can't remember where it's from.

But maybe I'm being a bit unfair.  Movies take plot ideas or even entire scenes from other ones and put a new spin on them, or the characters are interesting enough that we don't care about the lack of originality.  But the sad truth is that R.I.P.D. doesn't even try.  The characters are all stereotypes played with no real interest by their actors.  The situations are generic enough that you're easily able to predict the next thing with great accuracy.  How about the comedy?  Well, you need jokes and funny situations for that, and this movie only acts like there are, but most of the time, there aren't.  Well, then, "What about the action?", you might ask.  Unfortunately, that is lacking too.  There are very few action scenes, and they're either uninteresting, downright boring or hard to look at seriously due to the terrible CGI.  The very first scene in the film shows some CGI so bad you'd swear someone photoshopped a PSX cutscene in the middle of a live-action film.

I'm not gonna lie, there are a couple of interesting ideas on the film.  Dead people are unable to communicate with the loved ones who they are, so they look and sound different, and their speech mangles if they try to say who they are.  They all appear to other people as different humans.  Nick shows up as an old asian man and Roy as a blonde, attractive woman.  Indian food reveals the monsters' true aspect.  But in general, there's really not much good going on here.  Reynolds looks completely uninterested and Bridges accent is so terrible it makes you uncomfortable hearing it every time.

I really can't go and say this is a BAD film, since there's really nothing that's insulting, stupid or doesn't work for its premise, but there's an inherent laziness to the film.  It's like a made-by-numbers movie, as if they chose the plot, characters, setting and dialogue by throwing darts at a board and so it's hard to recommend, but I can't just tell people to avoid it.  It's really not hard to make an attractive film working almost exclusively with stereotypes (look at, say, Avatar), but you need to give your movie some appeal, which this film lacks.  Ultimately, it's not a bad experience, but it's a forgettable one.

R.I.P.D is a mediocre action/adventure movie but I suppose if children watch it, it's not that bad.  However the problem there is that children probably shouldn't be watching this movie due to all the sexual references.  While they're usually light-hearted references (thanks to Jeff Bridges in particular with his observant female ankle obsession) the bigger issues with the film lies in other key areas.

Whenever it tries to be action, it's hardly ever very exciting and is instead insanely whacky.  Whenever it tries to be sincere and emotional, the silliness that occupies the concept makes the few moments of emotion seem limp and forced so you end up not really caring about these segments either.  The storyline suffers as a result of the movie not really knowing what it wants to be, or rather, it constantly goes off in too many directions but never really feels concrete.  Basically Jeff Bridges being an obnoxious lawman makes this movie watchable.  Otherwise it's just constantly goofy.

Anyway, the story.  Ryan Reynolds and Kevin Bacon work together in the police department and end up stealing several gold bars from thugs.  Ryan suggests turning the gold in.  Kevin pretends to go along with it, until the perfect opportunity to kill his partner arises during an indoor shootout with Kevin's character knowing he can get away with it without anyone noticing.  Ryan dies as a result, and after winding up in a mysterious place outside of heaven he makes an agreement with a lady in charge of people's fate and comes back to his home city of Boston.  He soon finds himself teaming with Jeff Bridges character as the two of them work on cases around the city while occasionally stumbling upon Kevin Bacon's character communicating with Ryan's wife (concerning the gold and Kevin making an effort to cover his murder crime).  Yes Kevin Bacon plays the bad guy!  I hardly ever see that in movies he plays in.

However here's the catch- people can't SEE Ryan Reynolds the way he looked when he was alive.  Instead people see a hot supermodel.  The same goes for Jeff Bridges character.  This leads to several scenes that are supposed to be hilarious but never made me laugh one bit.

The animation is unusual.  It reminds me of Who Framed Roger Rabbit or perhaps Shrek in that real people interact with comic book-style animation in a way that makes the monster-like creatures really look like a part of reality.  Expect to see animated monster creatures walking sideways across the outside of building walls as Ryan Reynolds and Jeff Bridges attempt to shoot them down.  It's... odd.  The interaction between real people and animation was odd in Who Framed Roger Rabbit, and it's odd here.  The storyline of fighting crimes in a city is similar to Who Framed Roger Rabbit as well.  You will notice similarities between the two films from time to time.

Otherwise this is a tolerable action/adventure film but nothing worth going out of your way for.  I recommend waiting for it to come on TV and not actually purchasing the DVD.  It's not interesting enough.  Most of the children watching this probably won't be able to detect the inappropriate references anyway and will instead focus on the monsters so no worries there.

This, too, shall pass, Ryan Reynolds - but what the hell were you thinking? Somewhere lurking beneath the awful suck that is R.I.P.D. is a rollicking film. But something got lost in translation from Peter M. Lenkov's fun comic book out of Dark Horse to its silver screen adaptation. The faults comprise a wealth of poor choices made, ranging from choppy storytelling to crap CG to too obvious cribbing from Men in Black, Ghostbusters, and the Frighteners. Somewhere, Tommy Lee Jones and Will Smith aren't sweating it.

Our entry point character is Boston's finest Nick Walker (Reynolds), latest recruit to the Rest in Peace Department, the afterlife police force dedicated to safeguarding the living from them restless undead what have lingered past their mortal coil. Nick, baffled hombre murdered moments ago, is given a choice between final judgment and joining R.I.P.D. for one hundred years. You and I, with skeletons in our closets, most likely would've done what he does next. Comes that law badge manifesting, charring, on his chest - a pretty cool visual. Off he goes to track down the dead who've slipped thru the cracks, whose stay on Earth have rotted their souls.

Nick's joined up just when R.I.P.D. needs him most. He's partnered up with Roycephus Pulsipher (Jeff Bridges), an ornery U.S. marshall whose heyday was circa 1800. In the midst of Nick's orientation, they sniff out a conspiracy amongst the undead in Boston, a nasty scheme that, if successful, would make the dead rain down on Earth. There's a 3000-year-old artifact served up as the McGuffin. There's Indian takeout food to give the dead away. There's Bridges' dusting off his Rooster Cogburn accent. There's Steely Dan music getting piped into the R.I.P.D. office (it's never explained why).

Remember when Amazon used to pimp its Listmania feature? I hadn't seen that in a while. But right now I've this urge to make a new list, the theme of which is Worst Comic Book Movie. And on that list R.I.P.D. would've just gone toe to toe with Jonah Hex, Catwoman, and Son of the Mask for top honors. And yet, in spite of the film's massive clunkiness, Reynolds does his best to anchor things. Bridges, for his part, is always interesting to watch but he just may have been too clownish here, so over-the-top I didn't much care what happened to him. I did like the playfulness between him and Reynolds and that their investigative methods tend to inch toward the maverick side.

The R.I.P.D. trailer presented a hilarious gimmick that right away became THE hook for me. The gimmick proposes that the universe, in its sagacity, prefers to blindfold the living. It projects the R.I.P.D. peacekeepers as something other than themselves to mere mortals. So, back on Earth, Nick Walker appears as this old Chinese guy (James Hong) with a banana (but, really, his gun) and Roycephus resembles a voluptuous blonde bombshell (Marisa Miller). And while the film does occasionally make good use of the gimmick, I think it could've explored it even more, for even bigger laughs. Hell, I wanted extended scenes with Hong and Miller. I feel it's only one of several missed opportunities, just another botched element. The film tries but fails to ape what Men in Black did so well, which is strike a balance between its moments of levity and its dramatic beats. There's nothing much here to invest you emotionally, and this is factoring in Nick's pining for his grieving wife (Stephanie Szostak) and his maddogging of his erstwhile partner in Boston PD. Kevin Bacon and Mary-Louise Parker are wasted. There's this sense that plenty of Parker's material was excised, that we only catch a glimmer of her character's quirkiness. And the Bacon, he's just dull in a dull role in a dull movie. The CG is so obvious and overused it takes you right out of the film (okay, some of the bullet time effects were cool). R.I.P.D.'s referencing the fugitive undead as "deadoes" is numbingly lame. The deadoes tend to look more cartoonish than menacing. One doughy deado looks like the Michelin Man and Mike Myer's Fat Bastard had a late night encounter. Also, as someone typing out a review, I resent that there's so many damn periods in the film title. So, yeah, R.I.P.D., neutered and soulless, not only appropriates an hour and a half of your life, it may give you carpal tunnel as well.

I don't outright hate this film (I did give it 3 stars after all.)  But it could have been so, so much more.  My first complaint is that Ryan Reynolds's character is bland at best.  I didn't even hear any real emotion from him when he arrived at RIPD and was told all about the organization, his proposed role in it, and the benefits he could expect from joining up (I mean, the man literally just died...you'd think he'd need a little time to get used to everything.  Sure, there was some emotion at the funeral, but that was forced at best and dealt with with way too quickly.)  While this film employed a lot of the stereotypes of buddy cop films, its premise is interesting and the stereotypes that are employed mostly work...Lord knows I've seen plenty of films that did much worse in this area.  I do think things with our leads' new partnership were rushed in the beginning.  I get that, real or dead, new officers in a department aren't given days of orientation and instead "learn on the job", especially if they already have some police experience in their backgrounds...that is what senior partners are meant for.  But our buddy cops went from agreeing to be partners to trying to aclamate to one another to totally dissagreeing with one another to coming to terms and starting to work together on the plot's main case in the space of about fifteen or sixteen minutes...I know the movie's not in real time, but couldn't a little more of its ninety  or so minutes have been devoted to developing this relationship?  A single episode of Law and Order where a new partner was introduced spent more time on things like that.  Some of the jokes just fell flat ("Eternal Affairs" for example (also did they refer to it as "internal affairs" when Jeff Bridges character was first introduced?).)  Also, some things were hastily explained at the last minute as though the script writers just suddenly realized that the plot wouldn't make any sense otherwise (the Saint Christopher medal for example) and some things are mentioned once and then never explained at all ("blood of thyn enemy" for example.)  And what was with the guys' "catch phrase, "Relax, body"...does anyone see that catching on?  Again, this could have been a much better film if everyone had just put in as much effort as Jeff Bridges and Mary-Louise Parker, the only enjoyable and truly memorable parts of this picture.  I'm led to understand that this film was based on a comic series.  Well, we've all seen the hits and misses of comic book adaptations.  If you're a fan and you want this film to complete some kind of collection, go for it.  If you're a fan and you want to preserve what you love about the comics and not watch the film, that's fine too.  Maybe you're not a fan at all...I'll leave the purchasing decision in your hands no matter what.  Enjoy.

R.I.P.D.The idea of a cop being asked to chase criminal ghosts after his death is interesting. The plot that motivates the evil ghosts is a bit hard to take and the idea that they could escape from God's custody is absurd. The way these undercover ghosts are unmasked, ridiculous! It depends on acceptance of a judeo-christian narrative of God, heaven & hell and then suspends accepted tenets of that traditional belief structure to advance the plot. They would have done better to simply accept the common belief in ghosts, that wander the earth after death, and go with that, leaving God & judeo-christian traditions out. I'd like to see it played straight or comedically. The first half is a little slow as Ryan Reynolds seems uncertain how he wants to play his character. Jeff Bridges is a complete and totally satirical character from his first scene. I found Reynolds' angst, over his lost chance at an life based relationship, difficult to buy into. His sincerity seemed as though it was shot for another film, juxtaposed with comedic performances & ghostbusters style antagonists bursting through walls & spouting one liners. The second half, as both Jeff Bridges & Ryan Reynolds find their chemistry as comedic characters is fun. Kevin Bacon, a pleasant surprise. I followed him from subtle to intense to comedic and believed all the way. Mary Louise Parker's quirky performance was great, potentially iconic. I'd like to see a second film that follows up on these guys.

When policeman Nick and his partner get their hands on pieces of the Staff and Nick decides to turn it in instead of keeping it, the story begins.  No mention is made of where the two get the fragments, except that it comes from an arrest and should be in the evidence locker instead of in their possession. The story's a little reminiscent of the TV series Reaper in theory but the determination of Nick to bring his murderous partner to justice as well as see his grieving wife one more time offset that.

This supernatural buddy cop actioner never takes us anywhere we haven't been before.

The problem is there's not a whole lot of originality here and not much we haven't seen before done better. R.I.P.D. is major parts "Men in Black," with liberal sprinklings of "Ghost," "Beetlejuice," "Ghostbusters," "Always," "Blade Runner," a short-lived 1998 TV show called "Brimstone," and probably many others.

Ryan Reynolds plays a Boston cop who's having second thoughts about his recent decision to keep some gold he and his partner, Kevin Bacon, discovered on a recent drug bust. But before he can do anything about it, he is betrayed and killed. He is intercepted on the way to eternal judgment by an offer to join the "R.I.P.D." and reduce his post-mortal punishment through his service. The supernatural police department tracks down and eliminates dead folks, or "deados," who have avoided judgement by secretly hanging out on earth. Reynolds agrees and gets teamed with a feisty 1800's lawman turned afterlife crime fighter played by Jeff Bridges. Thus they embark in adventures that eventually lead back to Reynold's killer and a plot for the dead to take over the world.

So Reynold's character gets assigned back to Boston  and he thinks this is the perfect opportunity to reconnect with his wife, but it turns out that live folks see him and his new partner totally different than his previous appearance and devine internvention keeps him from actually telling his wife who he really is. Reynolds appears as an old Chinese man, played by James Hong (who is a much better actor than this outing lets him be), while Bridge's crusty western lawman appears as a hot buxom blonde played by Victoria Secret Model Marisa Lee Bertetta.

It bothers me that there's several things never explained - besides why they couldn't come up with a better name than "deados." When Reynold's character dies, he seems to have no choice than to head towards judgment. So how did these other folks manage to stick around? There's a particular kind of ethnic food that pursuades deados to reveal their true form, so how does that work, or is that just the writers exposing their prejudice? If these are just dead people, why are some of them monsters with multiple limbs, fingers, or even heads?

Bridges' character seems a lot like his Rooster Cogburn from True Grit, except this time he has both eyes and a lot more drawl. He often steals the show with Reynold's rookie playing the straight man.

The extras on this disk aren't all that strong, There's some minor deleted or extended scenes, a blooper reel, and a making of featurette which details how the R.I.P.D. concept was first hatched in the late 90's, and was a comic book before becoming a movie.

Andrew's Blu-ray Review: Brimming with wildly fantastic CGI marvels, extravagantly sensational action sequences that'll have eyeballs popping out viewers' heads, and a dazzling host of colourful characters, 'R.I.P.D.' 3D is a good shoot em' up film with plenty of action to add to the ambience of the film. It's a bizarre but admittedly imaginative blend of 'Ghostbusters' meets 'Men in Black' with heavy dabs of the supernatural, dashes of the western and a pinch of sci-fi that the 3D image makes the film look good.

Very loosely based on the comic by Peter M. Lenkov 'Demolition Man' and the script by Matt Manfredi and Phil Hay, the same tag-team that brought us such gems as 'Clash of the Titans.' The filmmakers inject the story with a series of excitedly over-the-top jokes, puns, and lots of visual gags. Yet, the entire film has at some parts of the film good humour and a witty spirit.

Ryan Reynolds, who looks as if he's breezing through the role completely bored out of his mind. The generally reliable actor spends much of his time staring at action occurring around him with an uninterested gaze, as if he's confused about the reasons he agreed to be in this. In the few moments in which he suddenly wakes up and shows mild interest, it feels as if he's reminded that he signed on because the pay check was good. His usually a lively personality and impeccable comedic timing are missing entirely, walking from one scene to the next in a lifeless daze, making the character quite unlikeable. Even the attempt at having Nick Walker [Ryan Reynolds] is a crooked cop with a heart and a loving wife Julia Walker [Stephanie Szostak] does little to improve the actor's noticeably stale and listless performance.

The only light at the end of this dark tunnel is Jeff Bridges doing a mix of Jeff "the Dude" Lebowski and Rooster Cogburn as Nick's new partner, Roycephus "Roy" Pulsipher. Showing him the ropes in the afterlife police force, such as how to expose "deados," where the dead  trying to evade final judgment and with threats of Indian food, Jeff Bridges's surly, old-timey U.S. Marshal is a hoot, excited at the sight of ankles and sometimes incoherently grumbling moans about his physical death. He has just reason for hating those darn coyotes.

The character serves as blatant comic relief but feels more like the main attraction, yet he's relegated to sidekick duties. Nick Walker dupes one of Roy's informants into revealing Bobby Hayes as his contact. They follow Bobby Hayes to Nick Walker's old house, where he "discovers" Nick's stolen gold. After arguing over the gold, R.I.P.D. Chief Mildred Proctor [Mary-Louise Parker] receives orders to remove them from the case and from active duty due to this exposure. Mildred Proctor [Mary-Louise Parker] learns from Eternal Affairs that the gold could be used to construct the Staff of Jericho, which will reverse the flow of souls from earth to the afterlife.

Director Robert Schwentke does what he can with the material, like getting the best from Jeff Bridges, but also delivers a good chunk of the action and the story's most dazzling moments with little sense of purpose or urgency. The screen is a flurry and commotion of dazzling effects that ideally should excite and thrill, but much of it feels like a waste of energy because we don't care a lick for any of the characters, except for the wily Roy. Other than Ryan Reynolds' vapidly dry presence, we suffer an emotionless Mary-Louise Parker as useless commanding officer Proctor and Kevin Bacon is nothing more than a real dead weight and a really bad actor. 'R.I.P.D.' But overall despite all the reviews I have read gives it a thumbs down, but I personally enjoy it very much and had a few good laughs on the way, but what helps this film is the 3D on this Blu-ray disc, but when I saw it in 3D at the cinema it was so very bad and at times totally unwatchable, I wish I had seen it in 2D.

Blu-ray Video Quality  'R.I.P.D.' 3D Blu-ray with a first-rate 1080p encoded image that often amazes with a variety of highly-detailed scenes. Shot digitally, the freshly-minted transfer reveals the tiniest wrinkles in Jeff Bridges' aging face and exposes every pore on Ryan Reynolds' mug. Mary-Louise Parker, of course, looks flawless, but a couple negligible blemishes are apparent, especially in close-up. Every hair and whisker on various characters is razor-sharp, and fine lines in buildings, clothing and furniture are distinct. However, I also detected a smidge of aliasing around a couple objects here and there, a few scenes seem suspect of artificial sharpening, and some sequences are a tad softer than others. Presented in its original 2.35:1 aspect ratio, the video comes with a varied and full-bodied colour palette. Primaries are quite energetic, adding to the movie's comedic feel, while secondary hues are very bold with plenty of warmth. Contrast is generally spot-on and well balanced, but in several moments the highlights run a bit hotter than normal, which tend to clip the whites in a few spots. Black levels could have been much stronger as they are, for the most part, pretty dull and lacklustre. The high-definition transfer is not a complete loss, but it falls short of perfection, but the 3D helps to bring the action to the screen so much better, than watching it in 2D.

Blu-ray Audio Quality  On the audio side of things, the supernatural comedy arrives with a highly enjoyable and often immersive 5.1 DTS-HD Master Audio soundtrack. The surround speakers are often quite active and bustling with the noise of the city, the chatter of a crowd or the hurried pace of a busy afterlife police station. Many of the quieter scenes come with some mild effects for ambience, but the action sequences are the real showstoppers, as a diverse assortment of sounds spread all around and envelope the listener with discrete directionality. Debris from explosions spread overhead, bullets whiz by discrete from the front to the back of the room and helicopters circle the room with flawless panning. In the fronts, imaging is a broad wall of sound, aided by the engaging score of Christophe Beck, which spreads evenly across the entire soundstage. Channel separation is incredibly well-balanced, as activity moves from one side of the screen to the other smoothly, and dialogue reproduction remains crystal-clear and precise in the centre. The mid-range is not hugely impressive or exceptionally dynamic, but it's detailed and distinct, allowing for every clang, pop and crack to be perfectly heard. The low-end is probably the most disappointing aspect because it often seems lacking compared to the action on screen. There's still plenty of bass to give the scenes a bit of oomph and weight, but it also seems pretty mild and tamed. Nevertheless, many find it quite exciting and I sure did.

The movie begins by introducing us to Boston cop Nick (Ryan Reynolds). Nick is having second thoughts about some gold that he and his partner Hayes (Kevin Bacon) took from a bust. He tells Bacon that he is going to turn his share in, but Bacon can do whatever he wants and Reynolds won't rat him out. Anyone who has ever seen a cop movie before knows where this is going.

Yep, Reynolds is killed in action. Boy, I wonder who pulled the trigger. He is taken up towards Judgment by a giant inverted cloud/volcano thing and is recruited by the R.I.P.D. The R.I.P.D. or Rest In Peace Department is an afterlife police force tasked with making sure that the dead make it to their final spiritual destination and do not stay behind on earth to plague the living. Some of the recently dead slip between the cracks because so many people die these days, and the system wasn't designed for this kind of volume. That seems like a major oversight, but never mind. Why do they need detectives if they know everything about everyone? For that matter, who founded the R.I.P.D.? How are they funded? Is it God? The government? I think its Bugs Bunny. Hey, its more explanation than the movie gives you.

From here the movie is one long list of clichs and bad special effects. The plot is fill-in-the-blanks screenwriting at its worst. Reynolds is the young wise-cracking rookie, and Jeff Bridges is the gruff, old-timey lawman who works alone and doesnt play by the rules. Bridges dialogue consists almost entirely of one liners pulled straight from the Wild West Clich Handbook. The humor in the film usually revolves around the fact that, to the rest of the world, Bridges and Reynolds do not look like themselves and are masked by, umSpiritual Camouflage, I guess. To every one else, Bridges looks like a Playboy Playmate, and Reynolds looks like an elderly Chinese man.

This sounds funny and could have been, but I am struggling to remember it being funny. There is one moment when it is amusing. A talent agent, seeing Bridges as a sexy blonde, tries to recruit him as eye candy in a music video. Bridges feministic tirade is actually pretty funny, but it is dragged down because we see Bridges and not the attractive woman the agent sees. It seems like every time it would have been funnier to see Bridges, they showed the blonde and vice versa. Reynolds Chinese disguise is a throw away gag and hardly figures into the film. There is a truly awful scene where Bridges eats with his mouth open and it is offensive on almost every level.

The effects in the movie were surprisingly cheap. The C.G. would have been dated in The League of Extraordinary Gentleman ten years ago, and to see it now is just insulting. They must have blown the entire budget on Kevin Bacons scenes near the end of the movie, because those were the only ones that seemed finished. The rest of the movie looked like test footage, with the exception of Reynolds death scene near the beginning where the visuals are actually quite nicely done. Unfortunately, his total lack of response to what would be an astounding moment for any human being makes the whole scene feel like what it wasan actor staring at a green screen.

RIPD is a movie about a recently slain cop (Reynolds) who joins a team of undead police officers working for the Rest in Peace Department and tries to find the man who murdered him.

Realistically this movie could have been called Men in Black 4 as it would have easily fit into that series of movie as it basically copies the idea of the original Men in Black and changes the aliens to dead spirits. Even the weapons used seem to be similar. The only things missing of course are Wil Smith and Tommy Lee Jones. Through most of the movie, I kept comparing the 2 in the roles to Smith and Jones and felt that the movie would have been better with them in the role instead of Reynolds and Bridges. I am not saying the movie was bad but felt it was decidedly average and could have been better. I also felt like the chemistry wasn't really there between Reynolds and Bridges. There are moments that they try to be funny but they seem to fall a bit flat in almost like a been there done that or seen that kind of way. For some reason at least to me, Reynolds brings a movie down as I still a bit irritated at his portrayal of the Green lantern which I feel ruined its chance as a superhero franchise.

The movie does try to have a bit of heart though with its almost Ghost like portrayal between Reynolds and his wife but it comes across as more weird than sweet and kind of dampers the heart that it tries to give the movie.

All in all, it is an ok movie to watch but really brings nothing we haven't already seen, especially if you are a MIB fan. The copied storyline and the lack of chemistry between characters brings this movie down to an average at best movie that some people might not feel worth to watch. Their mission is to find and kill "deados"...bad dead guys who are hiding out on earth to avoid "judgment."

Okay.  This movie is supposed to be a comedy, right?  Then....where were the laughs?  This movie was not funny.  It was not funny in the least.  Yes, it felt a little like Men in Black...but without any of MIB's charm, humor, cleverness....or good character development!

Ryan Reynolds as the main character is soooo bland!  Bland, bland, bland!  Nothing likable there at all.  And Jeff Bridge's character?  Well, I just found him irritating.  He's like a one trick pony.....always bringing up the past, and living up to his tough old west gunslinger clich of an image.

The two partners have fake i.d.s that determine how others see them.....Ryan Reynolds becomes a little old Chinese man, whereas Jeff Bridges becomes this (supposedly) hot blonde.  The so-called humor of these fake i.d.s is so juvenile!  Unless you are under the age of 17, you probably won't find this ongoing joke very amusing.

The "deados" in this movie also have zero charm.....at least the aliens in Men in Black and the ghosts in Ghostbusters were FUNNY!  These creatures are just flat out rubbery looking messes.

RIPD(released July 2013)stars,among others,Jeff Bridge,Ryan Reynolds,Kevin Bacon,Mary-Louise Parker and Stephanie Szostak. I had high expectations for this film. I generally love the work of its two main stars and the totally off the wall concept was intriguing. But the execution was far from what I was hoping for. This has the same look and feel of Men in Black,but with jokes that fall flatter than yesterdays pancakes,S/Fx,especially where the "monsters" are concerned,that look SO fake,and a very poor and predictable linear script.
The story takes place in Boston. Reynolds is a cop and his partner is Bacon. It seems the two had a bust where some gold almost fell into their laps,and at first Reynolds went along with his partner and kept some. They were about to retrieve more when Reynolds backs out. At a big bust with cops and bullets flying everywhere,Bacon wastes Reynolds. Reynolds,now dead,is taken skyward and lands in the office of Parker. She offers him two choices:he takes his chances with judgement or he joins the Rest In Peace Department. He takes the latter,and is immediately teamed up with Bridges.
Bridges is a crotchety guy from the western 1800s period. They do not hit it off at first,but you know by movies end they will be the best of buds.
During their first bust together,the suspect gets away. After a lengthy chase they get their man. They recover a piece of gold,which happens to be of the same type Reynolds and Bacon had been trying to obtain in real life. Bridges tracks down a lead at Fenway Park. They don't get much info,but Reynolds plays a hunch and leaves the gold with him. Sure enough,as the two sit outside,the suspect also comes out and gives the gold over to Bacon. Bacon goes to Reynolds home and recovers another piece of gold there. He then leaves and goes to the bus depot where Bacon hands over what gold he has to a "deado"(the dead who illegally walk the Earth).They grab the deado but he also gets away,and in fact is seen all over the city.
Back at RIPD headquarters,the two are suspended from the case. They find out the gold is in fact part of an old artifact,when put back together can create a vortex which essentially rains dead people down on Earth for eternity. Bridges and Reynolds most likely will be terminated in two days time,so the two do not sit around. They track down Bacon and as it turns out Bacon is also a deado in disguise. They bring him in,but while they book him,a silver sphere taken off of him joins together and its effect slows all but the criminal deados down. The deados all escape and head for the top of the Commonwealth building,where they assemble the artifact to create the vortex. As the vortex starts to open,Reynolds and Bridges start shooting their way through the deados to take the artifact apart. They make it and save the world. Back at HQ the two get pardoned and the film ends as the two drive away.
You gotta be kidding me? Oh,you aren't are you? Deado's!!?? How simple,familiar but juvenile a term is that? It sounds like Deadites from "Evil Dead",doesn't it? Geesh,were Bruce Campbell in this movie to give it some umphhh! While I was happy to see Bridges,I was not impressed with the chemistry between he and Reynolds. Nothing seemed to click,as between Smith and Jones in Men in Black. Speaking of which,this movie has Men In Black all over it,but it just doesn't have a quarter of the imagination and fun that MIB did. In that film the two main stars,as you recall,were hunting illegal aliens. Here we have the stars hunting illegal deados. As a matter of fact,if you listen closely to Bridges affectation of an 1800s lawman,it sounds VERY much like Rip Torn,Smith and Jones's boss in MIB.The so called"jokes" are nothing but. I laughed not once,but NEVER.Bridges and Reynolds had avatars,which is what mortals on earth see when looking at them;Bridges a sexy lady and Reynolds an old Chinese man. At the end Bridges gets a new identity for Reynolds,a girl scout with braces,wearing an appliance. Hilarious......not! The S/FX,as I said,are old and stale. In fact it is one thing that deters from the movie,big time. The deados are absolutely fakey looking all the way through. All that big budget spent on CGI...a waste.
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s w/r of 2:35 :1 and is clear and crisp. Extras include and featurette, deleted scenes and a gag reel.
All in all a BIG disappointment. The cast does the best with what tepid script they got,but it is to no avail. The jokes fall as flat as the S/Fx. It is a poor mans Men In Black. Sorry to say,give it a pass amigos!

This sounded like a fun premise: a murdered cop gets the chance to wipe some stains off his record by serving with a group of afterlife policemen who hunt rogue ghosts. A bit like a supernatural "Men in Black," really. Unfortunately, "R.I.P.D." didn't live up to its premise.

Nick Walker (Ryan Reynolds) is a cop with a secret. During a drug bust he and his partner turned up some mysterious chunks of gold which, in a moment of weakness, they hid instead of turning in. He wants to use the gold to make a better life for himself and his wife, but after a conversation with her, he decides to do the right thing and turn it in instead. But before he can do so, he's murdered by a close ally and finds himself shanghaied into the R.I.P.D.--the Rest in Peace Department. There, he's paired with sarcastic, out-of-control old-timey sheriff Roy (Jeff Bridges) and set to the task of hunting down rogue ghosts, or 'deados,' that plague humanity.

All of the characters are one-note: Nick is the freewheeling Action Good Guy, Roy is the Acerbic Old-Timer with a Hidden Tragedy, and it never gets any deeper than that. Mary Louise Parker is probably the most appealing as Proctor, the sarcastic Tough Police Chief, but she wasn't given nearly enough to do and seemed to exist mainly to prop up Roy and Nick. Kevin Bacon is Hayes, Nick's former partner, who I'm fairly sure was sleepwalking through 90% of the movie.

The story never moves beyond plain action movie setpieces with a minimum of supernatural trappings on top. I have a high tolerance for silly and insubstantial action, but "R.I.P.D." just felt mechanical. You could almost see it checking off the to-do list. "Okay, we have the high-speed chase . . . the moment where the stakes are raised because oh *#&$, the heroes messed up . . . the egregious slow-mo . . . Done. You're entertained now." No, "R.I.P.D.", I'm not.

I give it two stars for the promising premise and a few moments of genuine laughs. Overall, though, I'd say skip it.

"R.I.P.D." is yet another example of a film killed by early bad press. Based on the Dark Horse comic book, this supernatural action/comedy is quite a bit of fun. Is the storyline predictable and recycled from other films of this nature? Of course it is; but you don't stop riding rollercoasters just because one has the same amount of loops another one does at the other end of the amusement park.

After meeting his own demise, a crooked Boston cop (Ryan Reynolds) is given a choice in the afterlife. Join the forces of the "Rest in Peace Department" and hunt down Deados or take his chances on Judgment Day. He partners up with a former Wild West lawman (Jeff Bridges) to hunt down criminal souls who refuse to vacate the Earth after death and face their eternal punishment. The two discover a plot to reverse the tunnel to the afterlife, allowing millions of corrupt and angry souls to invade the world.

Jeff Bridges pours himself into the role of an old-fashioned Wild West sheriff struggling with the modern excesses of the world. Ryan Reynolds looks like he's having a good time, as well. You can tell Kevin Bacon loves playing a bad guy and he shows it here.

The DVD version of "R.I.P.D." includes a few bonus features. There are deleted and alternate scenes accompanied by a gag reel. A featurette entitled "Transferring 'R.I.P.D.' - The Making of" takes viewers behind the scenes of the film.

"R.I.P.D." is rated PG-13 for violence, sci-fi/fantasy action, some sensuality, and language including sex references. I agree with all of the above warnings. Also, the monsters in the movie are rather cartoonish and not as scary as one might think. There's nothing too over-the-top visually to be found. It's as safe as any of the "Men in Black" movies.

As you would imagine, any references to God are removed from "R.I.P.D." Instead, Jeff Bridges' character refers to the ruling power as "The Universe." However, there's nothing I would say is religiously offensive as far as content is concerned.

Although the CGI shows its limits quite a bit, it's not enough to rob "R.I.P.D." of the humor, wit, and energy it exudes. If you long for a light-hearted supernatural adventure you can enjoy while veg'ing out on the couch and eating popcorn, this is your movie. It very much wears its influences on its sleeve - a nice mix of "Men in Black" and a tamer "Constantine." Basically, just replace aliens with dead people who mutate into monsters and you have a good idea of what to expect.

Based on a Dark Horse Entertainment comic book by Peter M. Lenkov, "R.I.P.D" looks like a "Men in Black" with a twist. One rookie cop teams up with his veteran partner, tracking down the "monsters" in the human's world. The difference is, all "R.I.P.D" officers are dead people.

Ryan Reynolds is a young Boston cop Nick Walker who gets killed during a raid on a warehouse. In the afterlife he is recruited by Mildred Proctor (Mary-Louise Parker), head of the Boston division of the Rest in Peace Department, and starts working with a former 19th century US marshal Roycephus Pulsipher (Jeff Bridges).

So far the story is not bad. But the film suddenly loses momentum there. Capturing (or hunting down) CG-created "Deados "is not interesting enough. The main plot needs something more than Kevin Bacon's antagonist and the secrets of "gold." The "Ghost"-like subplot about Nick's wife Julia (Stephanie Szostak) is weak.

Actors all did great jobs. Bridges and Reynolds are just terrific. Watching deadpan Mary-Louise Parker is really fun. It is just that director Robert Schwentke ("Flightplan" "The Time Traveler's Wife" "Red") doesn't seem to know where the story should be going.

The tunnel pops him out and into the office of Mary Louise Parker. She gives Ryan a choice of either going to face judgment or joining RIPD Boston. She says the tour is 100 years, after which he'll face judgment but with a good recommendation.  Ryan accepts and is introduced to his partner, Jeff Bridges.  Jeff's character is a law man from the 1800's who was also shot dead by his partner.  The two go after a "dead-o" and stumble onto a plot to reverse the tunnel that takes the dead up to judgment.  If the plot is successful, it would cause all the dead people to rain down and pollute the earth.

A reviewer said he thought RIPD was too similar to the Men in Black series.  I disagree. In the Men in Black movies, the partners are people who are alive and are enlisted in an organization to capture aliens. In RIPD, the partners are people who are dead and are trying to capture dead people who have escaped judgment. Also, the plot in RIPD is about Ryan and Jeff stopping this tunnel from being reversed.  So I don't think RIPD is similar to Men in Black at all.  The plot is fresh, new and very entertaining.

Also, I thought Jeff Bridges was extremely funny.  Ryan Reynolds did a good job and fit the character he was playing.

"R.I.P.D." happens to be one of those movies that could have been something great had some fatal decisions not been made. The premise is a decent one.  A recently slain cop joins up with a band of undead police officers to police the undead who didn't want to leave earth, all the while investigating his own death and parting ways with his existence.  The first big problem that came out glaring from the get-go is the sickeningly close resemblance to another movie that also used an acronym as its title; "Men in Black" aka "M.I.B.".  Once Reynolds character, Nick, passes over, you can't help but feel like you've been here before with the strange characters and the weird partner and the white walls, etc. etc. etc.  They copied "MIB"'s style, look and replaced aliens with ghosts and you'd think they could have at least not used an acronym as well.

Then there's Jeff Bridges playing an old west sheriff named Roy.  The movie tries to be as funny and quirky as "Men in Black" but only once or twice does the comedy actually work.  I was thinking that maybe some more of the comedy would have worked had we actually been able to understand Bridge's mumbling incoherent words. He sort of did the same thing in 2010's "True Grit" and I remembered thinking the same thing then, although this time, it was even worse. If this is his normal voice, which it may be, then his career is in trouble.

As "Men in..." err, "R.I.P.D." plays out, the story is actually a really good one and it's a terrible shame that the creators didn't brainstorm a little longer to try and be more unique, but they didn't. In fact, the finale of the film is absolutely fantastic and the best part of the movie.  In the movies final moments the effects are outstanding and the emotions of the characters are fleshed out, giving "R.I.P.D." at least one thing to be positive about. Unfortunately, it took a long and painful time getting there.

Bottom line, this movie was poorly handled by director Robert Schwentke. A perfect example of how poorly it was handled is the use of one of the best gimmicks in the film. Nick and Roy don't look the same when they are earthbound. Nick looks like an elderly Asian man and Roy looks like supermodel Marisa Miller. It is a funny gimmick but even this is poorly used. There are many moments where it would have been better to have had Marisa Miller delivering the lines instead of Jeff Bridges. Regardless of how poor of an actress she was or is, we could have understood the words and it would have been funnier having her deliver some of Roy's lines. There's no excuse for wasting such a great gimmick. None.

Thanks to only being able to understand half of one characters dialogue, a funny gimmick that was horrendously handled until the final thirty seconds of the film and the obvious comparisons to "Men in Black", "R.I.P.D." is the hands-down front runner for the 2013 razzie awards. Will and Jaden Smith and their "After Earth" are thankful, as well as Robert Deniro from "Big Wedding".
